GRANT AND PROJECT SUMMARY 
 
Borrower  Mongolia 
   
Classification  Targeting classification: General intervention

Themes: Sustainable economic growth, regional cooperation 
Subthemes: Promoting economic efficiency and enabling markets,

Assessment  undertaken and the summary circulated to the Board of Directors 
of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and made public through 
the ADB website on 17 August 2007. 
   
Project Description  The  Government  of  Mongolia  is  proposing  to  develop  a 
748.4-kilometer  road  corridor  through  the  western  region  of 
Mongolia connecting Yarant at the People’s Republic of China 
(PRC) border to Ulaanbaishint at the Russian Federation border 
via Hovd and Olgiy, the aimag centers. Making up a portion of 
Asian Highway 4 and a component of the larger United Nations 
Economic  and  Social  Commission  for  Asia  and  the  Pacific-
designated  Asian  Highway  Network,  the  road  corridor  will  link 
Mongolia  with  both  the  PRC  and  the  Russian  Federation, 
facilitating the flow of goods and passengers between the three 
countries. Due to capacity constraints such as availability of grant 
funds,  the  proposed  road  corridor  will  be  developed  in  two 
phases. Under the Project, a 431.2-kilometer road from the PRC 
border  to  Hovd  aimag  (province)  center  will  be  developed  as 
phase I. Phase II will develop a road from Hovd aimag center to 
the  Russian  border.  The  Project  includes  (i)  road  safety 
improvement;  (ii)  community  development  to  maximize  the 
project’s poverty reduction impact; (iii) awareness and prevention 
of HIV/AIDS and human trafficking on the road corridor; (iv) pilot 
project on improvements to the road maintenance system; and 
(v) capacity  building  of  the  Ministry  of  Roads,  Transport  and 
Tourism (MRTT) and its provincial counterparts.  
   
Rationale  The proposed road corridor will strengthen Mongolia’s transport 
links to the PRC and the Russian Federation as well as other 
countries in the region. The Project supports ADB’s strategy for 
Mongolia,  which  focuses  on  promoting  sustainable  economic 
growth  and  social  development  by  allowing  for  more  market 
integration  and  movement  of  people,  resulting  in  broader 
economic  growth  and  reducing  geographic  isolation,  thereby 
reducing poverty. The Project also supports ADB’s strategy for the 
Central Asian region, which is designed to (i) secure access to 
profitable markets in large neighboring countries for exports from 
the  Central  Asian  republics;  (ii)  reduce  transaction  costs  and

ii 
facilitate  transit  and  transport  across  the  region;  (iii)  improve 
energy supplies for sustaining growth; and (iv) mitigate negative 
regional  outcomes,  such  as  environmental  degradation, 
desertification,  human  and  drug  trafficking,  and  the  spread  of 
communicable diseases. 
   
The  Project  supports  Mongolia’s  priority  development  plan  of 
building  roads  for  the  Asian  Highway  under  the  national 
development  strategy,  which  is  based  on  the  Millennium 
Development Goals. As part of the Asian Highway Network, the 
project road will serve as an important route for domestic and 
international traffic. The proposed road corridor will also facilitate 
sustainable economic growth in the two most western aimags of 
Mongolia (Hovd and Bayan-Olgiy), which had a poverty rate of 
38.7% in 2006; compared with the national average of 32.2% and 
20.4% in Ulaanbaatar. 
   
Impact and Outcome  The  impact  of  the  Project  will  be  the  promotion  of  regional 
transport  of  freight  and  passengers  via  the  Western  Regional 
Road Corridor and increased economic development and regional 
trade. The outcome of the Project will be an efficient and safe 
regional  transport  route  developed  in  the  western  region  of 
Mongolia to link Xinjiang Uygur Autonomous Region in the PRC 
and Siberia in the Russian Federation through Hovd and Bayan-
Olgiy aimags of western Mongolia. As part of Asian Highway 4, 
the road will help link Mongolia with the rest of Asia. 
   
Project Investment Plan   The investment cost of the Project is estimated at $112.22 million, 
including taxes and duties of $10.06 million.

Implementation  A project implementation unit will be set up under the Department 
Arrangements  of  Roads  of  MRTT  to  take  responsibility  for  implementation 
activities. The unit will be headed by a project director, who will be 
assisted by a full time project manager and a team of qualified 
technical, financial, and administrative staff. 
   
Executing Agency  MRTT 
   
Procurement  Goods and works financed by the ADB grant will be procured in 
accordance  with  ADB’s  Procurement  Guidelines  (2007,  as 
amended from time to time). Civil works for the project road will be 
procured through international competitive bidding. Equipment will 
be procured through national competitive bidding. 
   
Consulting Services  The  Project  will  finance  92.5  person-months  of  international 
consulting services: 16 for detailed design, 72 for construction 
supervision, and 4.5 for other services. The detailed design period 
is anticipated to begin in the first quarter of 2008 and last for the 
entire year. The construction supervision consulting services will 
be required from the middle of the second quarter of 2009 and 
extend through the completion of the road defects liability period 
at  the  end  of  the  third  quarter  of  2013.  The  Government  will 
finance consulting services for detailed design, while ADB will 
finance  the  construction  supervision  consulting  services.  The 
ADB-financed consultants will be recruited using quality- and cost-
based selection (80% technical and 20% financial weighting) and 
full technical proposal, in accordance with ADB's Guidelines on 
the Use of Consultants (2007, as amended from time to time). 
   
Project Benefits and  The Project will (i) improve the transport network in the region, 
Beneficiaries  allowing residents easier, less expensive, and faster access to 
social, health, and other services; (ii) increase the annual regional 
gross domestic product of Hovd aimag to 6% after completion of 
the  Project;  (iii)  help  increase  regional  transit  trade  tonnage 
through Mongolia’s western region by 25% by 2014; and (iv) help 
increase trade between the western region and the PRC and the 
Russian  Federation  by  15%  by  2013.  Income  of  targeted 
participants of the Project is expected to increase 10% annually. 
The expected results of the Project include (i) reduced travel time 
from Yarant to Hovd aimag center by 3 hours by 2013, (ii) reduced 
average border processing times for goods and passengers at 
Yarant by 1 hour by 2013, and (iii) traffic volume at the Yarant 
border  increased  by  15%  annually  from  2012  to  2015.  The 
economic internal rate of return for the Project is 16.3%. 
 
The Project will directly benefit road users, including passengers, 
traders, and transport providers, as well as local economies and 
labor. The environment of the region will be improved through 
reduction of dust generated by vehicles traveling over earth roads 
and elimination of multiple earthen tracks that currently exist along 
the proposed alignment. A considerable number of jobs will be

iv 
created by upgrading the road and provide the opportunity for 
poor households to exit poverty status. About 2,300 total jobs will 
be created for the road upgrade during construction. Of these, 
nearly 1,300 jobs will be for unskilled workers. Assuming that 80% 
of  unskilled  workers  will  be  hired  from  local  poor  households, 
1,040 unskilled jobs will be available. 
 
Risks and Assumptions  The Project is formulated to reduce technical, economic, financial, 
safety, and social risks. The main technical risks are associated 
with road construction in the area of Bodonch Canyon. The road 
alignment has been modified to mitigate this risk and allow for 
easier  road  construction.  During  construction,  monitoring  and 
contract management information systems will be set up to quickly 
identify and correct any technical problems. The contractors will 
be required to strictly enforce work safety rules and measures. 
The  extreme  climate  of  Mongolia’s  western  region  also  poses 
risks for construction and the long-term durability of materials. 
 
Maintenance  of  the  project  road  after  completion  may  be 
inadequate due to insufficient funding. This risk will be mitigated 
mainly through the introduction of a road user fee at the PRC 
border. A similar fee will be enforced at the Russian border after 
completion of phase II. Based on the traffic projections, the fee 
collected is adequate for annual maintenance of the project road. 
However,  the  financial  risk  associated  with  construction  and 
operation of the project road will depend on traffic volume and the 
signing of a tripartite agreement between Mongolia, the PRC, and 
the Russian Federation related to transit trade. The roughness 
index  of  the  road  should  be  3.0  immediately  following 
construction.  In  addition,  routine,  periodic,  and  rehabilitation 
maintenance works will be required to ensure the roughness index 
does not exceed 4.5. 
 
The Project does not involve any resettlement and has adequate 
mitigation  and  monitoring  mechanisms  in  place  to  minimize 
environmental impacts.

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed grant 
to  Mongolia  for  the  Western  Regional  Road  Corridor  Development  Project–Phase  I  (the 
Project). The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 
2.  Mongolia has a relatively large land mass and small population, resulting in one of the 
lowest population densities in the world; less than 1.5 per square kilometer in most of the 
country. Due to its large geographic area and relatively low population density, Mongolia’s 
transport  system  is  generally  not  well  developed.  Residents  of  remote  rural  areas  lack 
reasonable access to markets and social services, and are isolated from the country’s political 
and economic centers due to the poor road network. Within Mongolia, the far western aimags1 
are the most affected. 
 
3.  Furthermore, Mongolia’s geographic location, far from the sea and surrounded by two 
large neighbors—the People’s Republic of China (PRC) and the Russian Federation—makes 
external transport links via these countries very significant in terms of Mongolia’s international 
trade. A detailed road subsector analysis is in Appendix 2. To create favorable conditions to 
access the sea, improve the efficiency of transit transportation through the territory of foreign 
counties, and increase transit transportation through Mongolia, the Government of Mongolia 
(the Government) has decided to build key roads within Mongolia. The Government’s national 
development strategy based on the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs) identifies three 
main road corridors as priority projects for development; all are sections of the Asian Highway 
Network.2 The proposed road corridor, which is part of Asian Highway 4 (AH4), between Yarant 
at the PRC border and Ulaanbaishint at the Russian border, is one of the priority development 
projects for Mongolia and is included in national and regional3 development plans. The Project 
will develop the road section from Yarant to Hovd aimag center on the proposed road corridor. 
 
4.  The Asian Highway Network is a system of 141,000 kilometers (km) of standardized 
roads crossing 32 Asian countries with linkages to Europe and Central Asia endorsed by the 
United  Nations  Economic  and  Social  Commission  for  Asia  and  the  Pacific.  AH4  will  join 
Mongolia initially with the PRC and the Russian Federation, and then continue to link the 
country with neighboring Central Asian countries such as Kazakhstan. The proposed cross-
border linkage will help Mongolia improve its trade with Xinjiang Uygur Autonomous Region of 
the PRC (Xinjiang) and Siberia in the Russian Federation. It will also help to improve tourism 
and tourism-related businesses in western Mongolia. 
 
A.  Performance Indicators and Analysis 
5.  Road Network in Mongolia. Mongolia’s road network, including both state and local 
roads, totals approximately 49,250 km connecting 21 major cities and towns and 160 smaller 
villages (soums [local administrative area] and bags [local administrative subdivisions]). Of this 
total, state roads account for 11,219 km, and aimag and local roads for 38,031 km. Most 
Mongolian roads are gravel and earth; approximately 3.5% of the road network is paved.

6.  Within the western region, transport infrastructure is limited. Within the two most western 
aimags, Bayan-Olgiy allocates 0.31% of its land for the formal transportation network and Hovd 
allocates 0.2%. These percentages do not take into account the large number of unofficial earth 
tracks. As demonstrated by an analysis of the current makeup of the road alignment, of the 
748.4 km of the proposed road corridor, 104.3 km are gravel, 181.2 km are improved road 
(earth tracks that have been graded or received some kind of improvement), and 370.35 km are 
earth tracks. Only 92.55 km are asphalt, which includes 64 km of road recently constructed4 
from the Mongolia-PRC border. The project impact area of phase I comprises Hovd aimag. 
 
7.  Road Subsector Financing. The road subsector is financed from the state budget and 
three types of road funds: State Road Fund, 21 local (aimag) road funds, and Urban Road 
Fund.  In  accordance  with  the  1995  Law  on  Fuel  Tax  on  Gasoline  and  Diesel,  road  fund 
revenues comprise (i) allocations of a part of fuel taxes on gasoline and diesel; (ii) state budget 
allocations;  and  (iii)  other  donations  and  contributions  such  as  private  donations  to  the 
Millennium Road, fines, fees, and miscellaneous revenue. However, only the State Road Fund 
receives an allocation from the fuel taxes collected; the other two types of funds depend entirely 
on vehicle licensing taxes and allocations from aimag or municipal governments. 
 
8.  In recent years, State Road Fund revenues have not been sufficient to meet the needs 
of the Department of Roads of the Ministry of Roads, Transport and Tourism (MRTT). In 2005, 
MNT22.18 billion were allocated to the State Road Fund. In 2004, 1.4% of Mongolia’s gross 
domestic product (GDP) was allocated to the State Road Fund, but less than 0.3% of the GDP 
was used for maintaining the existing network, although about 1.0% was estimated to be 
necessary. Furthermore, of the road funds’ expenditures, maintenance makes up only about 
25% of the allocations. The rest is spent on new construction and, in the case of the State Road 
Fund, counterpart financing for projects funded by international financing institutions.5 External 
assistance to roads in Mongolia is outlined in Appendix 3. 
 
9.  Project Area. Hovd aimag has an area of 76,300 square kilometers and a population of 
91,687.6 The altitude varies between 1,142 meters (m) and 3,750 m. Hovd and Bayan-Olgiy 
aimags share a similar climate and set of challenges associated with road construction. Within 
Hovd aimag, the main economic subsector is animal husbandry, with 1.96 million head of 
livestock in the region. After construction of the project road, this subsector can be improved 
with the availability of new transport facilities. At present, the region has few mining activities or 
chemical industries that emit air, water, or soil pollutants. 
 
10.  GDP and GDP Per Capita. Mongolia’s five western aimags (of which two are crossed 
by the proposed road corridor)7 have a total population of approximately 400,000, representing 
16% of the nation’s total. In 2005, this region had a gross regional product of $138 million, 
representing 7.6% of Mongolia’s overall GDP. In per capita terms, Mongolia’s national GDP in 
2005 was $724 per person, in the western region GDP was $338 (footnote 6). The large and 
booming economies of the PRC and the Russian Federation represent large opportunities for 
economic growth in Mongolia through increased transit and trade.

11.  Poverty. The overall poverty rate for Mongolia is approximately 32.2%; 37% in rural 
areas and 27.9% in urban. More than one third of the population of the western region (38.7%) 
is classified as poor; only 20.4% of Ulaanbaatar falls within the same category.8 Within the 
country, the west has one of the lowest rates of urbanization, the largest average household 
size, and highest dependency ratio, which contribute to the comparatively high poverty.9 Within 
soums located along or near the project alignment, a 2007 sample survey of 334 households 
indicates that 20.34% are poverty households, with average monthly income per capita ranging 
from MNT17,000 to MNT27,000.10 
 
12.  Trade Flow. Overall foreign trade for Mongolia in 2005 amounted to $2.2 billion. The 
western region accounted for $24 million in exports ($5 million to the PRC and $15 million to the 
Russian Federation) and $53 million in imports ($20 million from the PRC and $25 million from 
the Russian Federation). However, trade flow to the PRC is increasing at a faster rate and, at 
present, traffic volume at the PRC border is more than three times the volume at the Russian 
border. Among the regions, Xinjiang has more than $5 billion of exports and just under $3 billion 
of imports. At the same time, east-central Siberia has $21.1 billion of exports and $3 billion of 
imports. These numbers suggest a sizable potential in terms of western Mongolia’s external 
trade and transit trade between Xinjiang and east-central Siberia. 
 
13.  Potential  Development  Activities. A large number of  mineral deposits have been 
identified in the western region. Most promising and commercially viable are coal deposits; an 
estimated reserve of more than 300 million tons is located near Hovd aimag (Khusheet). The 
coal and other minerals mined may be exported to the PRC, the Russian Federation, or other 
countries, resulting in increased foreign reserves and GDP, thereby positively impacting overall 
economic  development  of  the  country.  The  creation  of  mine  sites  will  impact  surrounding 
communities. While the project road is not built to accommodate heavy dump trucks used by the 
mining industry and new mining projects will need to secure alternate sources of transport for 
mineral  resources,  no  development  activities  will  take  place  in  the  western  region  without 
access to basic infrastructure facilities to support mining-related services. Services such as 
medical facilities, small business enterprises, and other related establishments all need to be 
constructed or expanded. Each of these will result in increased investment around the mine 
sites. These additional funds will support communities and provide much needed investment to 
increase the living standards of residents. 
 
14.  Coal  can  be  used  for  a  wide  variety  of  domestic  purposes  that  positively  impact 
development. It can be used in power plants and to provide heating to cities, villages, and 
households throughout the western region. The soums nearby these mines may gain revenue 
as a direct result of mine operations, including land-use taxes and water-use fees. Taking into 
account the fact that adequate transportation infrastructure must be in place to accommodate 
new developments such as the establishment of industrial parks to support small and medium-
sized  enterprises  in  the  region,  described  in  the  Western  Region  Development  Plan,  the 
proposed  road  may  result  in  the  generation  of  new  industries  and  establishment  of  new 
organizations that will increase revenue and employment for local communities. 
 
15.  Tourism. The Altai region along the project road is regarded as one of the few virgin or 
little-changed ecoregions in the world.11 Its uniqueness will attract more conventional tourism.

B.  Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 
1.  Problems and Constraints 
18.  The economic performance of the western Mongolia aimags has not been good in the 
last few years, with per capita GDP in 2005 being less than half of the national average. This 
raises issues such as the incidence of poverty given the low average income of all Mongolia 
even in purchasing power parity terms. Agriculture (mostly livestock) makes up just over 20% of 
Mongolia’s economy, but more than 60% of western Mongolia’s economy.13 The area has very 
little industry with the exception of meat processing and some small-scale mining, as well as a 
small tourism and hospitality industry. 
 
19.  In the without-the-road scenario, the economic performance of the western aimags will 
continue  to  lag  because  of  structural  weaknesses  and  infrastructure  shortcomings.  Out-
migration will continue both to Ulaanbaatar and to Kazakhstan, where ethnic Kazakhs of Bayan-
Olgiy aimag have established relationships and the petroleum industry is booming. Xinjiang and 
parts of Siberia are also growing rapidly and may attract migrants from western Mongolia. Any 
significant  population  growth  is  unlikely  without  improvements  in  infrastructure  and  related 
policy,  program,  and  project  changes.  Therefore,  the  new  paved  road  can  help  bring  the 
development potential of the region to reality. 
 
20.  Customs  Processing  Times.  At  the  Yarant  border  point,  clearance  times  are 
approximately 3.5 hours, often taking 2 hours on the PRC side and 1.5 hours on the Mongolian 
side. The primary causes of the difference in processing times relate to the relatively inadequate 
facilities14 and different procedures applied by custom officials of the two countries.

2.  Government and Asian Development Bank Strategies 
21.  Mongolia’s landlocked location between the PRC and the Russian Federation, and its 
remoteness  from  developed  international  and  domestic  markets  are  major  constraints  to 
international development. The Government of Mongolia has identified increasing investment in 
road construction and rehabilitation as a means to reduce the country’s isolation from world 
markets and improve the accessibility of isolated communities. The Economic Growth Support 
and Poverty Reduction Strategy identifies this emphasis on road rehabilitation as one of the 
main issues. Improving the Western Regional Road Corridor will be a large step forward in 
reducing geographic isolation within the region. 
 
22.  The  project  road  will  help  the  Government  meet  the  objectives  identified  within  its 
Comprehensive National Development Strategy for Mongolia, which is based on the MDGs. 
Among these objectives are expanding and developing the road network and connecting aimag 
and regional centers and the capital city by paved roads; improving the care and maintenance 
of  national  and  local  roads;  and  reducing  the  negative  impacts  of  road  vehicles  on  the 
surrounding environment, population, and traffic movements.15 These goals and strategies are 
in line with the transport sector strategy for Mongolia developed with the assistance of the Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) (footnote 5).  
 
23.  The  Project  supports  ADB’s  operational  strategy16 for  Mongolia  which  focuses  on 
promoting  stable  economic  growth  and  inclusive  social  development  by  allowing  for  more 
market integration and movement of people. This is to result in economic growth and reduced 
geographic isolation, and thereby reduce poverty. The Project also supports the ADB strategy 
for the Central Asia Regional Economic Cooperation (CAREC), which is designed to (i) secure 
access to profitable markets in large neighboring countries for export from the Central Asian 
republics; (ii) reduce transaction costs and facilitate transit and transport across the region; 
(iii) improve energy supplies for sustaining growth; and (iv) prevent negative regional outcomes, 
such as environmental degradation, desertification, human and drug trafficking, and the spread 
of communicable diseases. The CAREC Transport and Trade Facilitation Strategy endorsed by 
the Ministerial Conference is based on six priority corridors that link various Eurasian regions 
and markets. By upgrading air, sea, road, and rail infrastructure and services in these priority 
corridors along with those on secondary access routes, the cost and time of transporting goods 
and  people  will  be  reduced,  and  thus  the  competitiveness  of  CAREC  countries  improved, 
leading to higher sustainable economic growth and improved living standards. The project road 
is part of the CAREC transport corridor number four (AH4). 
 
24.  ADB’s country strategy and program (2006–2008) for Mongolia reaffirms the need to 
improve the accessibility of isolated communities addressed in the Economic Growth Support 
and Poverty Reduction Strategy.

III.  THE PROPOSED PROJECT 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
26.  The impact of the Project will be the promotion of regional transport of freight and 
passengers via the Western Regional Road Corridor and increased economic development and 
regional  trade.  The  outcome  will  be  an  efficient  and  safe  regional  transport  route  that  is 
developed in the western region of Mongolia, linking Xinjiang in the PRC and Siberia in the 
Russian Federation, by way of Hovd and Bayan-Olgiy aimags in Mongolia. The project road 
represents a portion of the AH4, an internationally designated road by the United Nations 
Economic and Social Commission for Asia and the Pacific.  
 
27.  The growth of gross regional product for western Mongolia for 2003–2005 was around 
3%; less than 50% of the gross national product for Mongolia (7.5%) for the same period. Once 
the Project is implemented, the gross regional product for western Mongolia is expected to 
increase  at  rates  between  4.5%  and  7.0%  per  year  through  2035.  Additionally,  the  gross 
regional product per capita growth rates are anticipated to range between 4.5% and 5.6% over 
the same time horizon. Employment opportunities will increase and out-migration will decline, 
resulting  in  an  annual  rate  of  population  increase  between  1.0%  and  1.5%.  If  additional 
improvements are made to the border facilities, growth figures are expected to be even higher. 
 
28.  In addition to stimulating economic growth within Hovd aimag, the aims of project road 
construction include (i) regional transit trade tonnages increase by 25% during 2007–2014 and 
(ii)  trade  between  the  western  region  and  the  PRC  increases  by  15%  during 2007–2014. 
Specific goals relating to transport of passengers and freight along the route include (i) average 
speed on the road increases from 40 km per hour to 60 km per hour by 2013; (ii) travel time 
from  Yarant  to  Hovd  aimag  center  decreases  by  3  hours  by  2013;  (iii)  average  border 
processing times for goods and passengers at Yarant decreases by 1 hour by 2013, and 
(iv) traffic volume at the Yarant border increases by 15% annually from 2012 to 2015. 
 
B.  Outputs 
29.  Main Road. A 748.4 km road stretching from Yarant at the Mongolia and PRC border to 
Ulaanbaishint at the Mongolia and Russian border will be developed in two phases. Under 
phase I, a 431.2 km road from Yarant to Hovd aimag center will be developed. The output for 
the Project will be the improvement of a 431.2 km road between Yarant and Hovd aimag center. 
The  road  will  be  built  to  Mongolian  category  III  road  standards  (determined  by  the  traffic 
volume), with two lanes and a cross section consisting of carriageway widths of 3.5 m and 
shoulder widths of 1.5–2.0 m. This proposed cross section meets the requirements of class II 
roads of the Asian Highway Network (Appendix 4). Implementation of civil works will begin in the 
second quarter of 2009 for the first construction package of the project road (Bodonch Canyon

Three road maintenance centers will be established along the project road (approximately one

maintenance centers will be undertaken along the project road according to a set schedule to 
ensure that benefits resulting from decreased vehicle operating costs and fuel savings continue.

established road maintenance centers will procure new equipment to supplement the equipment 
of  the  existing  road  maintenance  center.  This  new  equipment  includes  a  grader,  bitumen

32.  Road Safety. Following the upgrade of the road, vehicle speeds are likely to increase, 
resulting in greater potential for accidents. To mitigate against this and other hazards, measures 
such as the installation of guardrails where necessary, road signs, pavement markings, rest 
areas, and kilometer posts are proposed. Additionally, the project road will be designed to 
improve sight distances, providing drivers with more advance warning of obstacles on the road 
or approaching vehicles. Strict enforcement of axle-load limits for trucks traveling along the 
project road will improve road safety, as well as extend the life of the road surface. Road safety 
audits at the detailed design and preopening stages will be undertaken to secure road safety on 
the project road (Appendix 7).

C.  Special Features 
37.  Regional Cooperation. As a large landlocked country, Mongolia depends on its two 
neighbors, the PRC and the Russian Federation, for access to world markets and economic 
development.  The  PRC  and  the  Russian  Federation  dominate  Mongolia’s  external  trade. 
However, lack of roads leading to the PRC and the Russian Federation is a constraint. The 
majority of Mongolia’s external trade is carried on the existing north–south rail line, which 
connects Suhbaatar at the border with the Russian Federation and Zamyn-Uud at the border 
with the PRC. The ongoing road development along the rail line (footnote 19) will help improve 
Mongolia’s flexibility and limited capacity to handle exports and imports with its neighbors. Even 
after this development, Mongolia will have only one paved road corridor connecting north and 
south. To improve its trade and tourism, Mongolia needs a number of similar road corridors. The 
Western  Regional  Road  Corridor  is  considered  as  the  next  most  important  trade  link  to 
Mongolia.  
 
38.  The Project will develop a part of Mongolia’s second north–south paved road corridor 
link, which is part of the Asian Highway Network. The route is identified as AH4. From the north, 
the AH4 will connect western Mongolia to Barnaul and Novosibirsk in east-central Siberia in the 
Russian Federation and from the south it will connect to Urumqi in Xinjiang. Moving westward 
from both Barnaul and Xinjiang, the AH4 will connect to several other AH roads that will link with 
Central Asian countries such as Kazakhstan and Kyrgyz Republic. These connections will help 
to link western Mongolia to the entire region.  
 
39.  The CAREC program is also playing a key role in improving the region’s infrastructure 
and facilitating trade in western Mongolia. Mongolia’s participation in this organization and the 
proximity of other members that are experiencing strong economic growth cycles (e.g., the PRC 
and Kazakhstan) provide increased opportunities for both interregional and international trade.

IV.  PROJECT BENEFITS, IMPACTS, ASSUMPTIONS, AND RISKS 
A.  Traffic Forecast 
60.  The Project will increase the corridor’s capacity to meet the demand for transport and 
reduce transport costs, travel time, and accident rates. The development of the proposed road 
corridor  will  provide  employment  opportunities  during  and  after  construction  and  will  be  a 
conduit for increased economic growth and higher incomes. Annual average daily traffic on the 
proposed road between Yarant and Ulaanbaishint is forecast to grow from 826 passenger car 
units in 2013 to 2,309 in 2022, with an average annual increase of 12%. After 2022, annual 
average daily traffic growth is expected to slow to 11% per year, reaching 6,480 passenger car 
units by 2032. The traffic projections consider the (i) growth in traffic during the past 6 years, 
(ii) traffic generated by expanded economic activities, and (iii) traffic surveys (Appendix 14).  
 
61.  Under the Project, the Yarant–Bulgan–Hovd section of the road will be completed. The 
partial completion of the road corridor is expected to affect cross-border traffic and is projected 
to generate 70% of the total estimated traffic flow for the Yarant–Bulgan section and 50% for the 
Bulgan–Hovd section. 
 
B.  Economic Analysis 
62.  Construction  of  the  road  will  provide  a  large  stimulus  to  the  economy  through  the 
estimated $112.22 million project cost. Once the road is in place, the cost of transportation will 
be  lower,  and  hence,  business  costs  will  be  lower,  providing  an  ongoing  stimulus  to  the

14 
economy. The cost of imported goods will decrease and the net realization from exports mainly 
connected with animal husbandry will increase, thereby improving terms of trade for Mongolia. 
Moreover,  as  this  area  of  the  country  has  little  industry  and  almost  no  import-competing 
industry, very few offsetting losses can be anticipated. Like many developing regions, western 
Mongolia has relied on local cheap natural resources as the basis for the little industrial activity 
that exists. Thus, an abundance of land became the source of a livestock industry, which in turn 
led  to  meat  processing,  fiber  production  (cashmere  and  wool),  and  hides  and  skins.  The 
opportunity for future expansion of the number of livestock is limited because overgrazing and 
desertification already present problems. The new road will improve the situation, as it will 
reduce the large number of parallel dirt tracks (up to 100 on some open stretches of the existing 
alignment), which are highly destructive to surface vegetation. 
 
63.  Economic  viability  mainly  depending  on  projected  traffic  flow  is  more  realistically 
analyzed for the entire proposed road corridor rather than phase I (the Project) only. The overall 
economic internal rate of return (EIRR) is estimated by comparing the project case with a base 
case. The Project, with shorter travel time, safer design, and better road conditions, will reduce 
vehicle operating costs and accident risks along the corridor. The economic costs are the cost 
of capital, which includes physical contingencies, land acquisition, and the cost of operating and 
maintaining the project roads, including the replacement of depreciated equipment. Economic 
benefits include (i) savings in vehicle operating costs resulting from the shorter distance and 
improved road conditions, (ii) time savings for road users, and (iii) trade-related benefits through 
cross-border facilitation. At 16.3% per year, the EIRR demonstrates the economic viability of the 
proposed  road  corridor.  Results  of  the  sensitivity  analysis  confirm  the  robustness  of  the 
economic viability. Even with changes in the key variables such as construction costs, reduction 
in traffic volume, and project delay by 1 year, the EIRR is above the cutoff rate of 12%. The 
results suggest that costs would need to increase by 49.4% to reduce the EIRR to 12%, while 
benefits would need to be reduced by 33.1% to reduce the EIRR to 12% (Appendix 15). 
 
64.  For phase I (the Project) only, under which only the Yarant–Bulgan–Hovd section will be 
completed, the EIRR is estimated to be 13.6%, which is still economically viable but lower than 
the EIRR for the entire proposed road corridor. Although the road is upgraded for the section of 
Yarant–Bulgan–Hovd by the completion of phase I, the amount of induced international and 
local traffic will be affected, compared with the original traffic forecast where the entire road is 
completed. This will lead to deferment of achieving economic benefits and, in turn, forces the 
EIRR of phase I to be lower than the EIRR of the entire road corridor. 
 
C.  Cross-Border Transport Facilitation 
65.  ADB and its partners in the CAREC program place a high priority on trade facilitation 
because of the potential significant gains from increased trade in the region (footnote 21). One 
of the main benefits from the proposed road corridor is increased cross-border trade among 
Mongolia, PRC, and the Russian Federation, which will contribute to regional cooperation and 
integration under CAREC. CAREC has confirmed the designation of the AH4 route as its priority 
transport corridor, and the route will receive priority for CAREC trade facilitation support. As 
agreed  at  CAREC’s  6th  Transport  Sector  Coordination  Committee  Meeting,  Mongolia  will 
implement harmonized cross-border procedures at its border crossings. This will significantly 
improve the movement of vehicles across the border. ADB is currently studying the details of 
cross-border trade between Mongolia and the PRC under a regional TA.25 The TA outputs will 
help improve cross-border trade between Mongolia and the PRC. Mongolia has already signed

Cooperation Program. Manila.

15 
bilateral cross-border agreements with the PRC and the Russian Federation, and is expected to 
sign a tripartite agreement as well.  
 
66.  Trade figures of the western Mongolia's two neighboring provinces of the PRC and the 
Russian Federation are sizable. In 2005, for all transport methods, the Russian Federation as a 
whole exported $418 million to Mongolia and $12.9 billion to the PRC ($1.7 billion of which went 
to Xinjiang). In focusing on just the east-central Siberian region, its total exports amounted to 
$21.1 billion and imports to around $3 billion. Of these, $38 million were exported to Mongolia, 
while $65 million were exported to the PRC. In looking at goods flowing the other way, east-
central Siberia imported $5 million from Mongolia and $73 million from the PRC. In the east-
central Siberian region, the main industries are dedicated to metals and minerals, synthetic 
rubber, petrochemicals, iron and steel, machinery, and pharmaceuticals, all of which can be 
exported by road to the PRC via Mongolia. Food processing and forest-based industries are 
also present, but to a lesser degree. Western Mongolia also imports almost all of its energy 
supplies from Siberia and needs to expand its energy supplies to sustain its growth. The project 
road will facilitate easier and more reliable supply of such needs. 
 
67.  Xinjiang has more than $5 billion of exports and just under $3 billion of imports. Xinjiang 
exports to the Russian Federation amount to $593 million. The PRC’s exports to the Russian 
Federation include agricultural products, manufactured goods such as consumer durables, and 
garments/textiles. These numbers suggest a sizable potential in terms of western Mongolia’s 
external trade as well as transit trade between Xinjiang and east-central Siberia. Currently, 
exports  from  the  Russian  Federation  to  Xinjiang  via  road  transport  enter  mainly  through 
Kazakhstan. 
 
68.  Also of importance for this analysis is the fact that three cities in east-central Siberia, 
Novosibirsk,  Barnaul,  and  Biysk,  are  important  transport  and  distribution  centers  with 
Novosibirsk being a hub for rail, air, and road transport; while Barnaul is an important rail and 
road center with connections to the western part of the Russian Federation and Kazakhstan. 
Biysk is a significant transshipment point for rail transport. Goods that flow to these locations 
from other parts of the Russian Federation could be loaded into trucks for further transport to 
Mongolia or to the PRC via Mongolia. Likewise, goods arriving in Urumqi can be transported 
east by using the PRC’s road and rail network. Currently, for transit traffic to and from the 
Russian Federation and the PRC, the options could involve travel through Kazakhstan or central 
Mongolia. However, transit through Kazakhstan can be cumbersome and costly due to the 
longer distance involved. 
 
69.  An improved paved road that provides easy access to both Urumqi and Novosibirsk 
would reduce travel time and vehicle operating costs. Some traffic that has been using the 
Kazakhstan route could be diverted to the project road. 
 
D.  Financial Analysis 
70.  The Project is expected to cost $112.22 million, with ADB providing $37.6 million, and 
the Government providing $74.62 million. Using these funds, the project road will be constructed 
from the south to the north, with ADB financing being used for the following sections: Bodonch 
Canyon and Baga Ulaan Pass to Manhan soum. 
 
71.  To maintain the road so that it does not exceed an international roughness index of 4.5, 
annual  maintenance  will  be  required  along  with  periodic  maintenance  every  8  years  and 
rehabilitation every 16 years. For the entire project road, the annual cost of maintenance is

16 
anticipated to be $0.67 million, with $9.31 million for periodic maintenance and $25.0 million for 
rehabilitation (Appendix 16). 
 
72.  To offset costs associated with maintenance and ensure sustainability, a road-user fee is 
proposed at the PRC  border.26 It will be levied on all vehicles that have not paid any of 
Mongolia’s  current  road-user  fees.  The  fee  will  be  fixed  after  considering  factors  such  as 
affordability and type of vehicle. Given the projected traffic volume and estimated user fees of 
$5 for light trucks, $7.50 for medium trucks, and $10 for heavy trucks, the annual amount 
collected  at  the  border  is  estimated  to  be  higher  than  the  need  for  annual  and  periodic 
maintenance and will cover a major part of the rehabilitation cost as well. A discounted road-
user fee may be charged on Mongolian vehicles. Fees payable will be set on an affordability 
basis and be reviewed periodically. 
 
E.  Poverty Reduction and Social Strategy 
73.  Stakeholder  Consultations. More than 6,200 people were consulted during project 
preparation through household surveys, origin-to-destination surveys, public meetings, business 
surveys, and the environmental impact assessment (EIA). Discussions involved all aspects of 
the project road, including benefits and other potential impacts. The consensus is that the 
project  road  will  positively  impact  the  region  by  reducing  dust  generation,  decreasing 
geographic isolation, and increasing access to goods and markets. 
 
74.  Social Benefits. The construction and upgrading of the project road will result in the 
creation of a considerable number of jobs for communities located along the alignment. The 
Project is the key to development in Mongolia’s western region and without the Project, no 
development activities stated in the Western Region Development Plan will be accomplished as 
no infrastructure facilities are in place for commercial development. The newly created jobs will 
allow households to bring extra income and be trained in road construction and/or maintenance, 
which can be applied to future opportunities. Assuming that the contractor will hire 80% of the 
unskilled labor from poor households in the project impact area, 1,040 jobs for the poor will be 
created.  Approximately,  200  of  these  unskilled  workers  who  gain  experience  in  road 
construction can be absorbed into the road maintenance centers. Further opportunities will arise 
from travelers on the road spending money in the soums. The overall result of the road on the 
poor in the project impact area is the elevation of 19.1% of poor households from poverty status 
(Appendix 17). 
 
75.  Control and Mitigation of Epidemic Diseases. As with any road construction project, a 
danger is the spread of disease as a result of bringing a mobile population of construction 
workers  and/or  mobile  professionals  into  the  alignment  communities.  At  the  same  time, 
communicable diseases in the local communities could be spread to other areas as workers and 
professionals return home. HIV/AIDS is a primary concern, however, its incidence in Mongolia is 
low. To mitigate against this and other diseases, construction contracts should require (i) only 
legal  workers  are  employed,  (ii)  HIV/AIDS  and  STI  information  is  provided  to  workers, 
(iii) condoms are made available to workers, (iv) HIV/AIDS and STI testing is provided, and 
(v) HIV/AIDS and STI monitoring will be allowed. 
 
76.  As  part  of  earlier  ADB-funded  TA  in  Mongolia  connected  to  the  Regional  Road 
Development  Project  (footnote  19),  materials  have  been  developed  for  HIV/AIDS  and  STI 
education  indicating  their  associated  dangers,  along  with  human  trafficking.  Utilizing  these 
materials, the TA benefits can be transferred to the Project at very little cost. All construction

77.  Ethnic Minorities. In Hovd aimag, the population of the project area is almost entirely 
Mongolian; in Bayan-Olgiy, the population is primarily Kazakh minority. The project road will not 
have a negative impact or make significant changes to their livelihoods or culture. To extend

upgrading and maintenance. 
 
78.  Gender  Impacts.  The  road  upgrading  could  play  an  important  role  in  generating 
economic growth in the region, thereby increasing opportunities for women and men to generate 
income  for  their  families  and  achieve  financial  security.  This  increased  revenue  for  local 
governments means that kindergartens and other facilities are more likely to be built to enable 
female heads of households to work, support their families better, and ensure that their children 
get an education. MRTT will ensure that all the employment opportunities will be given and 
Mongolian labor standards are applied to everyone regardless of gender. 
 
F.  Land Acquisition and Resettlement 
79.  The proposed project road follows an existing earth track alignment. No households will 
lose land; houses; agricultural plots; crops; trees; fixed assets; business; incomes or livelihoods; 
or access to facilities, services, or natural resources. 
 
G.  Environmental Assessment and Management Plan 
80.  The Project is environment category A. The EIA was prepared and a summary EIA for 
the  Project  was  circulated  to  the  Board  on  17  August  2007.  The  EIA  assesses  the 
environmental impact of selected alignments of the project road and prescribes environmental 
protection and mitigation measures, valued at $1.47 million. Discussions with the World Wide 
Fund for Nature, Wildlife Conservation Society, and Specially Protected Area Administration 
Department in Ulaanbaatar indicate that the project road will have little impact on existing 
wildlife and their migratory patterns, primarily because the road corridor is an existing alignment 
that has been used for many years. Project implementation is expected to positively impact the 
environment by reducing dust, decreasing soil degradation, eliminating multiple earth tracks 
currently being utilized, and contributing to economic development of the region. To minimize 
the impact of the Project on environmental aspects, the Ministry of Nature and Environment will 
supervise and monitor the environmental aspects. Capacity of the ministry will be strengthened 
by providing 36 person-months of national consulting. 
 
H.  Risks and Assumptions 
81.  The  Government  has  given  assurance  that  phase  II  of  the  project  road  will  be 
implemented in 2010. Failure to do so may result in reduction of the anticipated economic 
benefits of the Project. 
 
82.  The project design considers potential technical, economic, financial, and social risks. 
The main technical risks are associated with road construction in the Bodonch Canyon area and 
weather-related conditions. To minimize the technical risks, (i) the proposed alignment through 
Bodonch Canyon has been rerouted to reduce the earthworks and blasting needed; (ii) slope 
protection measures, retention walls, and permafrost protection are proposed; (iii) road safety

18 
equipment will be installed; and (iv) additional bridges will be constructed to facilitate river 
crossings. With regard to weather, the design incorporates standards of the Mongolian-issued 
Road Climatic Zones and Geotechnical Conditions. 
 
83.  The social risks primarily involve HIV/AIDS and STI transmission. To mitigate against 
these risks, construction contracts will contain clauses providing means for providing HIV/AIDS 
information and testing, and stating that workers who violate the rules and regulations will be 
immediately  terminated  and  subject  to  prosecution  if  laws  have  been  broken.  Appropriate 
mitigation measures to counter these risks are in place in the social development action plan 
and the environmental management plan. MRTT demonstrated a high degree of ownership in 
preparing and committing to implementation of these action plans. 
 
V.  ASSURANCES 
84.  In  addition  to  the  standard  assurances,  the  Government  has  given  the  following 
assurances, which are incorporated in the legal documents. 
 
85.  Counterpart  Financing.  The  Government  will  ensure  that  all  funds  and  resources 
necessary for construction, operation and maintenance, and management of the Project are 
provided in a timely manner. The Government will take all necessary measures, including the 
provision of additional funds to ensure that the Project is successfully implemented, managed 
and operated after construction is completed. 
 
86.  Development  of  Phase  II.  The  Government  will  ensure  that  adequate  funds  are 
allocated to phase II of the proposed road corridor and implementation of phase II is started not 
later than 31 December 2010.  
 
87.  Construction Quality. The Government, through MRTT, will ensure that (i) the project 
road is constructed in accordance with national technical standards; (ii) project construction 
supervision,  quality  control,  and  contract  management  are  conducted  in  accordance  with 
national  standards  and  internationally  accepted  practices;  (iii)  ongoing  civil  works  under 
government financing are executed in accordance with national technical standards; and (iv) the 
completed sections of the project road are adequately maintained. 
 
88.  Environment.  The  Government,  through  MRTT,  will  ensure  that  (i)  the  Project  is 
designed, constructed, and operated in accordance with environmental laws and regulations of 
the Government and ADB’s Environment Policy (2002), the EIA, and summary EIA; (ii) the 
environmental  management  plan  (EMP)  and  the  mitigation  measures  included  therein,  as 
specified in the EIA and summary EIA, are properly implemented; (iii) the EMP is updated at the 
engineering design stage, and incorporated into bidding documents and civil works contracts; 
(iv) any adverse impact on the environment that may arise from project implementation activities 
is promptly mitigated or minimized in accordance with the EMP; and (v) implementation of the 
EMP,  including  any  safety  breaches,  violation  of  environmental  standards,  and  corrective 
measures taken thereto, is reported at least semiannually to ADB. 
 
89.  Community Development. The Government, through MRTT, will manage and monitor 
community development activities proposed under the Project by the project implementation unit 
and agreed by ADB. 
 
90.  Local  Employment. The Government, through MRTT, will cause the contractors to 
employ unskilled workers from local areas to maximize the employment of local poor people,

19 
including ethnic minorities, who meet the job and efficiency requirements for construction and 
maintenance of the project road. The Government, through MRTT, will ensure that such workers 
are provided with adequate on-the-job training. 
 
91.  Labor Standards. The Government, through MRTT, will ensure that all the employment 
and labor standards provided in the applicable laws and regulations of Mongolia are complied 
with, and in particular, that all civil works contractors engaged under the Project will (i) provide 
timely payment of wages on at least a monthly basis; (ii) provide safe working conditions to all 
workers, with such requirements being included in the civil works contracts and monitored by 
the construction supervision consultants; (iii) provide employment opportunities to women and 
ethnic minorities, where appropriate, and pay equal wages to male and female employees for 
work of equal value; and (iv) do not employ child labor in the project works. 
 
92.  Health Risks. The Government, through MRTT, in coordination with the appropriate 
agencies identified by the Government, will cause the contractors to disseminate information on 
the risks of STI, including HIV/AIDS, to their employees during project implementation. MRTT 
will cause the appropriate agencies to disseminate similar information to transport operators and 
local communities living in the project area during project implementation and operation of the 
project road. The Government, through MRTT will cause contractors to monitor health risk 
control. 
 
93.  Commercial Development in the Project Area. To ensure that the expected benefits 
of  the  Project  are  channeled  through  to  the  local  community,  the  Government  will  start 
implementing the Western Region Development Plan approved by the cabinet on 28 September 
2005 for soums and aimag centers along the project road within 2 years after completion of 
construction of the project road. 
 
94.  Monitoring  and  Evaluation.  The  Government,  through  MRTT,  will  monitor  and 
evaluates  the  project  impacts  including  poverty  indicators  and  community  development 
activities,  with  the  assistance  of  the  consultants,  to  ensure  that  the  project  facilities  are 
managed effectively and the benefits, particularly to the poor, are maximized. The Government 
will cause MRTT to (i) employ a qualified domestic institute, prior to project implementation, to 
carry out the monitoring activities; (ii) ensure that local governments, including local statistics 
offices,  collect  the  data  to  measure  the  relevant  indicators  prior  to  and  during  project 
implementation, at completion, and annually 3 years thereafter, with the frequency as specified; 
and (iii) submit to ADB the reports summarizing the key findings of monitoring. 
 
95.  Resettlement. The Government will ensure that the Project does not entail any land 
acquisition and/or resettlement. In the event of any unforeseen resettlement, (i) the Government 
will inform ADB and prepare a resettlement plan according to relevant laws and regulations, and 
ADB’s Involuntary Resettlement Policy (1995); and (ii) civil works will not start until ADB has 
reviewed and approved the resettlement plan. 
 
96.  Ethnic Minorities. The Government will ensure that the Project does not have any 
adverse impact on the livelihood of nomadic herders and ethnic minorities living in the project 
area. In the event of any unforeseen impact on the livelihood of nomadic herders and ethnic 
minorities, (i) the Government will inform ADB and prepare a plan according to relevant laws 
and regulations, and ADB’s Policy on Indigenous Peoples (1998); and (ii) civil works will not 
start until ADB has reviewed and approved the plan.

prevent overloaded vehicles entering the project road after its completion. 
 
99.  Road User Fees and Maintenance. The Government will ensure that all collected road-
user fees are directly used for the maintenance and rehabilitation of the project road and the 
project road is well maintained after its completion. In the event that road-user fees collected are

undertake maintenance work by allocating adequate funds from the Government budget.

PROJECT ROAD ENGINEERING 
 
1.  The project road will be designed according to Mongolian category III standards, in 
accordance with Mongolia’s Road Design Standard CNR 21-01-00. This category of road is 
made up of two-lane, undivided roads with an average volume of traffic, and a design speed of 
100 kilometers (km) per hour (h), 80 km/h, or 60 km/h, depending on the terrain.1 The cross 
section involves lanes of 3.5 meters (m) width and 1.5 m shoulders on each side. The proposed 
cross section and road design standards are consistent with standards for class II highways of 
the Asian Highway Network. 
2.  The road is proposed to have a design life horizon of 2013–2032, with traffic volume 
expected  to  reach  4,841–5,573  vehicles  per  day  by  2032.  Given  these  projections,  
5-centimeter  (cm)  asphalt  concrete  surface  course  pavement  is  recommended,  with  the 
following pavement design. 
3.  Existing  Road  Segments.  Inventory  and  condition  surveys  were  carried  out  for 
21 existing road subsections ranging in length from 12.4 km to 73.2 km. Two of the inventoried 
stretches (from Yarant to Uyench and near Hovd) are paved with asphalt; one section is gravel 
road.  With  the  imprint  of  maintenance  activities  such  as  culvert  renovation,  raising  of 
embankment and grading can be seen. In many stretches, side drains are blocked or eroded. 
4.  The remaining road sections are categorized as earth or improved earth road. Some of 
may have had selected earth covers earlier, which have not been replenished and graded. In 
terms of their present condition, they are to be treated as earth roads only. The earth road 
segments have poor capacity for transport traffic and are liable to be bypassed through the use 
of  parallel  unformed  tracks  (except  in  approaches  to  passes  and  bridges,  where  traffic  is 
constrained  to  use  the  existing  earth  roads).  The  sections  with  improved  road,  with  the 
exception of the Bodonch Canyon area, do not have drainage ditches. 
5.  Of the 431.2 km road length, currently, 83.8 km is asphalt (including the 64 km from the 
border with the People’s Republic of China to Uyench River), 12.4 km is gravel, 121.5 km is 
improved road, and the remaining 213.5 km is earth road. 
6.  Alternative Alignments. In the preliminary road design, alternative alignments were 
proposed and considered throughout the corridor. The first is located between Bodonch and 
Manhan. The selected alignment includes two mountain passes and was found to be a cheaper 
and shorter alternative than the longer and flatter option to the east. The second alternative 
alignment is located in Hovd city, where the options include constructing the road through the 
city or bypassing it. The bypass option was selected, meaning the road will pass Hovd city to 
the east, as this option eliminates land acquisition issues, utilizes a 19 km section of existing 
asphalt pavement, and keep trucks out of the city center. 
7.  Bridges and Culverts. Along the 431.2 km alignment, construction of 32 new bridges 
and rehabilitation or reconstruction of 12 existing bridges is proposed. Of these, 27 new bridges 
will be constructed in the Bodonch Canyon section. In this same section, all 8 existing bridges 
will be rehabilitated or reconstructed. Due to the narrow canyon, the presence of Bodonch 
River,  and  the  limited  sight  distances  in  this  section,  the  alignment  has  been  altered  to 
incorporate new bridges, thereby increasing safety. Additionally, this new alignment will reduce 
the amount of earthworks and blasting needed to construct the road.

benefits derived from extending the construction season.

ROAD MAINTENANCE CENTERS 
 
1.  The highest priority for roads over the past few years has been maintaining the road 
system. This is still far from complete but is receiving attention by international organizations. 
Large economic losses in terms of increased vehicle operating costs and reduced economic 
production and development will result if the existing road infrastructure is allowed to continue to 
deteriorate.  The  maintenance  of  the  state  roads  is  a  priority  because  they  are  essential 
economic growth corridors both for domestic and international trade (including serving as part of 
the trans-Asia network and providing direct access to international gateways), while providing 
mechanisms for achieving the Government’s regional development objectives via improved 
integration and communication within Mongolia. 
 
2.  In addition to the economic factors, proper road maintenance is key to securing road 
transportation  services  in  the  project  area  due  to  the  natural  characteristics  of  western 
Mongolia. The proposed project road is situated in the high mountainous area of the western 
region. Roads can be covered with sand and snowdrifts due to strong winds; soil erosion at road 
embankments can occur due to rain and snow; rockfalls can endanger road users traveling at 
middle/high speed near steep and rocky hills; vast variations of cold and hot weather affect road 
users, road infrastructure, and surroundings; and the steep gradient causes surface water to 
flow rapidly carrying small stones that block drainage. The influence of storms during the spring 
and fall is greater than in other regions of the country and slush can often occur, causing 
vehicles to slide. Additionally, due to summer rainfall, periodic floods can be expected.  
 
3.  Current road maintenance capability in the project area is inadequate to cover increasing 
requirements for road servicing because or the relative isolation and low road network density. 
To remedy this, road maintenance centers will be established along the proposed project road 
approximately every 100 kilometers: in Bulgan Soum, Baga Ulaan Pass, and Manhan Soum. 
The international roughness index of the road will not exceed a value of 4.5 at any given time, 
thereby ensuring that benefits resulting from decreased vehicle operating cost and fuel savings 
will continue. 
 
4.  Major responsibilities of the maintenance centers include the following: 
 
(i)  Maintain pavement, base course, and subbase course; prevent sliding pavement, 
provide surface dressing, repair cracks, and provide overlay and rehabilitation. 
 
(ii)  Patrol, remove snow, spread sand on icy roads, and support stuck vehicles 
during winter with special attention to pass areas such as Baga Ulaan Pass. 
 
(iii)  Inspect drainage facilities, and provide necessary maintenance work if these are 
blocked or damaged. 
 
(iv)  Clear rockfalls and check/repair the road infrastructure such as slope protection, 
retaining walls, and revetment structures at least twice a month or more in pass 
areas with steep slopes, such as Bodonch Canyon. 
 
(v)  Check  culverts  with  hillside  ditches  and  provide  repair  work  especially  at 
Bodonch Canyon; flash floods can cause soil erosion, and water-coved roads 
and floods can occur during spring and summer.

ROAD SAFETY IN MONGOLIA 
 
1.  Mongolia has a serious road traffic safety problem; traffic accidents have a significant 
economic cost, as well as social and personal impacts on victims and their families. The number 
of accidents increased nearly 7 times between 1995 and 2006, from 860 to 5,911. Fatalities 
from road accidents in urban areas increased by 28.6%; injuries increased by approximately 
46.2%.  In  rural  areas,  accidents  increased  by  27.7%,  while  deaths  remained  relatively 
unchanged and injuries increased by 34.2%. Rural areas accounted for approximately one fifth 
of total accidents and two thirds of deaths nationally. In this respect, rural areas are a more 
significant source of road accident fatalities. 
 
2.  The analysis of national data on accidents and vehicle ownership shows that while the 
number of accidents per 1,000 vehicles increased more than 27.7% in the 12-year period, 
deaths per 1,000 vehicles decreased by 9.3% and injuries by 7.1%. In terms of severity, 
national statistics show the following trend: deaths resulting from accidents between 1995 and 
2006 remained relatively unchanged (0.34 and 0.33); injuries decreased from 1.01 to 0.25. 
 
3.  The  Road  Law  and  Road  Transport  Law  detail  the  duties  and  functions  of  each 
administrative level to ensure that roads are properly maintained and the traffic flow is well-
managed and safe for the general public. 
 
4.  Road Safety Issues. With the exception of the southernmost 64 kilometers at the 
People’s Republic of China–Mongolia border and short sections passing through Hovd and 
Olgiy and at the Russian Federation border, the project road is not paved, making vehicle travel 
difficult, particularly for large trucks crossing the mountain passes. Road safety is a concern in 
hilly and mountainous areas as vehicles try to maneuver around bends where sight lines may 
be limited. 
 
5.  In populated areas, speeding vehicles and the presence of pedestrians and livestock 
unwary  of  oncoming  traffic  pose  a  safety  threat.  With  the  proposed  road  upgrading  and 
improvement, both traffic volume and speed will increase, correspondingly heightening the risk 
of road accidents.  
 
6.  The road segment from Bulgan soum [local administrative division] to the junction for 
Must soum is approximately 170 kilometers and covers a wide range of topography. It includes 
a river crossing of Uyench River, currently without a bridge; a river valley along Bodonch River 
with nine bridges crossing the river; and a 2,860-meter mountain pass. The alignment of the 
section  has  numerous  very  sharp  horizontal  curves  with  limited  sight  distances  in  narrow 
sections. This road segment will require alignment modifications to provide a wider carriageway 
and better horizontal radii and sight distances. 
 
7.  Due to hilly and mountainous terrain, rockfalls may occur in some areas. These are 
potentially hazardous to vehicles that try to avoid them. In certain areas, structural measures 
may be necessary such as riprap revetments, rock cladding, or retaining walls.  
 
8.  Safety railings or post barriers are generally absent in the winding segments of the 
project road. At a minimum, adequate additional width or wider sections at road bends is 
needed to accommodate turning vehicles.

E.  Secondary Benefits from Potential Development Activities 
 
7.  Some important secondary benefits from potential development activities generated as a 
result of the road upgrading are not included in the economic analysis of the Project. Once they 
can be measured, the projected EIRR could be much higher. Taking into account the fact that 
an adequate transportation infrastructure must be in place to develop mining industry, the 
proposed  road  may  result  in  the  generation  of  new  industries  and  establishment  of  new 
organizations that will result in added revenue and increased employment for local communities. 
 
8.  Although only an open pit tungsten mine (Khovd Gol) is currently operating in western 
Bayan-Olgiy, a silver deposit near Tsagaannuur in northeastern Bayan-Olgiy is being evaluated 
and may be developed within the next several years. The silver mine (Asgat) has a reserve of 
approximately 2,300 tons, but is located in a remote area that is not easily accessible. Most 
promising and commercially viable is a coal deposit with an estimated reserve of 300 plus 
million tons, which is located near Hovd aimag (Khusheet). The coal and silver mined may be 
exported to the People’s Republic of China, Russian Federation, or other countries, resulting in 
the increase of foreign reserves and gross domestic product, thereby positively impacting the 
overall economic development of the country. The development of mines will positively impact 
employment in the region. Skilled and unskilled labor will be needed to mine the silver or coal, to 
provide support services to the mine, and to transport the minerals to their ultimate destination. 
 
9.  Domestically, the coal can be used for a wide variety of purposes that positively impact 
development. It can be used in power plants and to provide heating to cities, villages, and 
households  throughout  the  western  region.  The  soums  (local  administrative  subdivisions) 
nearby these mines may gain revenue as a direct result of mine operations, including land use 
taxes and water use fees. The creation of mine sites will also positively impact surrounding 
communities. Services such as medical facilities, cafes, bars, hotels, gas stations and repair 
facilities, and other related establishments will need to be constructed or expanded. Each of

these businesses will result in increased investment around the mine and the continual flow of 
funds being directed to them throughout the lifespan of the mine. These additional funds will 
support the communities and provide much needed investment to increase the living standards 
of area residents. 
 
10.  Although tourism infrastructure remains limited, this will likely change as travel becomes 
easier and more reliable with improved access. As the Altai region along the project road is 
listed as one of the virgin or little changed ecoregions in the world,1 its uniqueness will provide 
attractions for more conventional tourism. Various national parks, nature reserves, important 
bird habitat areas, a Ramsar site (convention on wetlands), as well as a range of archeological 
sites also have potential to attract international tourists. Jet service between Ulaanbaatar and 
Hovd began recently, reducing the flight time between the cities from over 4 hours to 1.5 hours, 
which is also likely to contribute to tourism.

FINANCIAL ANALYSIS 
 
1.  The  individual  road  sections  are  consolidated  into  three  construction  packages  of 
contiguous  sections.  In  addition,  a  package  including  road  sections  that  may  not  require 
international financing institution funding is included in the financing plan to indicate the full 
amount of Mongolian Government contributions to the entire road improvement project. 
2.  The  proposed  financing  for  the  $112.22  million  project  road  includes  $37.6  million 
equivalent grant financing from the Asian Development Bank (ADB) (33.5% of the total cost) 
and $74.62 million equivalent from the Government (66.5% of the total cost). 
3.  Three types of maintenance work must be financed after completion of the Project:  
(i)  routine annual maintenance such as pothole repair, crack sealing, guardrails, 
debris removal, and snow removal; 
(ii)  periodic  maintenance  (every  8  years),  such  as  major  surface  treatments 
(e.g., chip seal); and 
(iii)  rehabilitation of the wearing surface to include scarification of the surface and 
application of complete overlay (every 16 years). 
 
4.  The existing road user fees and taxes collected throughout Mongolia can be considered 
a road user contribution to the cost of road maintenance and development. However, a new 
road user fee is needed to capture non-Mongolian registered traffic utilizing the project road. 
5.  In determining the value of the road user fee, the annual funding needed for road 
maintenance must be examined along with the volume of traffic expected to pay the fees. The 
annual cost for maintenance is $0.67 million ($1,562 per kilometer [km]), with $9.31 million 
needed every 8 years and $25.00 million every 16 years. The rate structure for road user fees 
collected at the border should be structured so that these maintenance costs are covered by the 
fees. Assuming a road user fee of $5 for light trucks, $7.50 for medium trucks, and $10 for 
heavy trucks, and based on the traffic projections at Mongolia’s borders with the People’s 
Republic of China,1 the road user fees will equal the needed routine maintenance costs before 
2013. The surplus fees collected each year will be applied to additional costs for periodic and 
rehabilitation maintenance. The cumulative surplus will be sufficient to fully cover the periodic 
and rehabilitation maintenance costs, eliminating the need for additional Government funds. 
6.  Construction of the project road is expected to be completed by 2013, meaning that 
periodic  maintenance  will  be  required  in  2020  and  rehabilitation  will  be  required  in  2028.

cumulative user fee surplus between 2013 and 2021, when combined with the road user fees 
collected in 2022, is sufficient to fully cover the periodic maintenance cost. With the same 
assumptions,  the  surplus  accumulated  between  2023  and  2029  would  fund  the  costs  of

I.  POVERTY ANALYSIS AND STRATEGY 
A.  Linkages to the National Poverty Reduction Strategy and Country Partnership Strategy  
In the Economic Growth Support and Poverty Reduction Strategy (2003), the Government of Mongolia emphasizes road 
network development because roads play a significant role in accelerating economic growth and reducing poverty. In the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) country strategy and program (2006–2008) for Mongolia, road development is identified as 
important for regional market integration and facilitating the movement of people, goods, and services thus leading to 
economic development and poverty reduction.  
B.  Poverty Analysis                                                         Poverty Classification: General intervention 
According to the national household survey—the 2006 household income and expenditure survey—32.2% of Mongolia’s 
population is living below the poverty line and 38.7% in the western region. In Bayan-Olgiy, 53% of the population have 
monthly consumption expenditure below the poverty line of MNT20,200 and in Hovd 46%. According to the social survey of 
the project area, all aimags (provinces) rank the rehabilitation of international and local access roads as a top priority in their 
development agenda. Due to the proximity to the People’s Republic of China (PRC) and Russian Federation, Bayan-Olgiy and 
Hovd aimags import about 75% of their energy, food, consumer goods, and construction materials from the two countries. The 
Project will greatly contribute to improved linkages to markets in the PRC, Russian Federation, and Kazakhstan through the 
Russian Federation; and improved access to industrial and tourism employment opportunities and social services. The Project 
will lead to lower transport costs, better access to deliver essential goods from neighboring economies to local communities, 
and employment opportunities during construction. The following are common issues in the area related to poverty:  
(i)  High unemployment. Lack of job opportunities is one of the main issues. In the western region, the unemployment 
rate was 5.3% in 2004, compared with 3.6% in the country. No significant industry is currently in place to boost the 
regional economy.  
(ii)  Poor medical facilities. Every soum (local administrative division) has trained medical assistants and primary 
health care centers with minimal facilities. However, problems still remain because of the lack of modern facilities for 
special treatment at clinics and hospitals, nurses and doctors have not been fully trained in modern treatment 
techniques, and costs for medical treatment are higher for poor households in the region.  
(iii)  Unsecured drinking water resource. In Bayan-Olgiy aimag, 12.8% of households have access to water from 
water distribution stations, compared with 94.5% of households in Hovd aimag; the remainder use water from 
natural (unprotected) sources such as springs, rivers, and lakes.  
II.  SOCIAL ANALYSIS AND STRATEGY 
A.  Strategy to Address Social Issues 
1.  Create Local Job Opportunities. The implementing agency will require contractors to maximize hiring labor under the 
Project. The Project will generate about 1,300 unskilled construction jobs: 80%, or 1,040 jobs, will be targeted for poor 
households. In addition, a separate community-based local road and maintenance project funded by the Japan Poverty 
Reduction Fund will be implemented to generate additional local employment.  
2.  Improve Medical Facilities and Drinking Water Resources. The Project allocates $150,000 for community development 
activities in the project area to respond to social needs such as drinking water development, public baths, vocational training, 
and equipment for community-based enterprises.  
B.  Consultation and Participation 
1. Provide a summary of the consultation and participation process during project preparation. 
More than 6,200 people were consulted during project preparation through public meetings and socioeconomic surveys. 
Various stakeholders participated in the consultation process, such as central and local government officials, environmental 
experts, social workers, teachers, doctors, herders, business persons, and road users. Active participation from women in 
public meetings was confirmed during the fact-finding mission. These processes have enabled: (i) increased awareness and 
local support, (ii) expression of opinions and concerns on social and environmental aspects, (iii) relevant suggestions for 
western  region  and  local  road  designs  (e.g.,  road  alignments  and  access  roads)  and  future  road  projects,  and 
(vi) identification of potential community development projects.

The participatory activities are an ongoing process that will continue during project implementation.

C.  Gender and Development 
1.  Key Issues.  
Women in the western aimags do not currently experience gender problems in terms of women’s rights and access to 
education, health, and other services. However, the country gender assessment identifies growing concerns on emerging 
gender gaps. Despite women’s higher rate of participation in the workforce and educational attainment, the per capita gross 
domestic product for women is half of that for men ($2,730 versus $1,379) according to 2006 Gender Gaps Report by the 
World Economic Forum. A factor is women’s predominant occupation in contracting sectors and men’s dominance in growth 
sectors. Other gender concerns are (i) significantly higher incidence of poverty among households headed by women, (ii) 
women’s unemployment rate is double that of men, and (iii) time poverty caused by increased demand for rural women’s labor 
in food production for household consumption. Also the incidence of domestic violence and alcohol abuse is growing.
